content.description: A short but fun route.  Climb the vertical dark wall with some good moves.
content.location:
Follow the approach trail down to the cliff, pass the first three short routes. This is the next route left of

We The People

.

content.description: Fun climb that is short and a good warmup.  Climb left around a low roof and follow a small right-facing corner to the chains.
content.location: Follow the approach trail down to the cliff, pass the first three short routes.  This is the next route and is almost directly across from the knotted rope on the West Side.

content.description: A fun, little warmup.
content.location: This is the third route you encounter as you enter the canyon travelling upstream on the East side.  It is at the base of a small ramp which you ascend to access the next two climbs.

content.description: A fun little warmup with a crux at the top.
content.location: This is the second route encountered as you enter canyon on the East side travelling up river.

content.description: This is an OK little route with a contrived finish.
content.location: It is the first route on the east side of the river as you hike upstream.

content.description:
Sylas is a fairly short but enjoyable and fun route on the east side of the canyon. It has a brief but somewhat technical & cryptic crux that is well-protected. I believe this is a good route for the budding 5.11 climber to project and the 5.11+ climber to go for the onsight.

Climb up the slab, and clip the 1st bolt as for

Mexican Burrito

. Now head straight up into the arcing, right-facing dihedral above. Creatively make your way up this corner, clipping bolts out right.

Now get into position as the corner joins with the perplexing headwall above. Spread your legs, and smile as you make crux moves over the small roof onto the vertical wall. Figure out the best way to clip the last bolt, pull onto the ledge, and clip the anchors. It's over before you know it.
content.protection:
1 long draw for the 1st shared bolt of

Mexican Burrito

, 4 quickdraws for the route itself. There is a 2-bolt anchor on ledge at the top with lowering carabiners.
content.location:
This is to the right of

Mexican Burrito

and left of

420

. It shares a 1st bolt with

Mexican Burrito

.

content.description:
Stem the outside of the chimney (stay out of the chimney!). After three bolts, move left to the upper featured face and last two bolts of

The Happy Hooker

.
content.location:
Ten feet right of

The Happy Hooker

is a crappy looking chimney.

content.description: I linked the bottom slab to the top crack (done as TR by JS before).  The start is on a slabby ledge to more slabby ledges then a dihedral, go up and right to another dihedral and blocky face/cracks to ledge.  P2 up the crack to top.
content.protection: Lowe tri-cams, nuts and single rack of Camalots; double rope rap from top.
content.location: This is right in front of a huge tree on the black slab.

climbs.name: Skyfall
climbs.fa: Skylar Smith, May 25, 2020 -- bolted by Jimmy Simmons?

content.description:
Named after my decking experience while being lowered off of

Brady's Route

a few weeks ago, the direct line to

Sand Dollar

, "Skyfall" is born. This was listed as an old project in Tim Kuss' Durango Sandstone guidebook bolted by Jimmy Simmons? Although there is a 2 bolt anchor before the roof starts, I climbed this as one big 35 meter pitch. Knot your ends, and bring a 70m! Start with a fun, easy, and well-bolted slab (right of

Conch

), and climb to the base of the roof. Use a couple double length runners for rope drag purposes, and then bust up steep 5.12 terrain on good holds. Please take caution pulling on the first jugs over the lip! They are a bit hollow sounding! After a little choss, rest up, and fire a V6ish sequence on a thin seam before linking up with

Sand Dollar

.
content.location:
This is two bolted lines to the right of

Brady's Route

/

Sand Dollar

, or one route right of

Conch

. Locate the well bolted slab (I believe the first pitch of

Flat Track

), and climb straight up and through the roof to

Sand Dollar's

anchor.

content.description:
Climb the same start as

Brady's Route

, and go straight up the corner to a bolt.  Climb on amazing rock with some bolts close together and some really far apart.  I was working this and took a 30 or 40 foot fall.  The crux is at the top of the route where the face turns close to blank.  God speed.
content.location:
Lemon Reservoir (Duhh) Simonizer has the same start as

Brady's Route

but goes straight up the obvious corner.  If you find yourself traversing in a seam climber's right, you're probably being dumb and on

Brady's Route

.

climbs.name: The Sand Dollar
climbs.fa: Bolted: Jared Odgen,  FFA: Chris Barlow, 8/20/11

content.description:
Climb

Brady's Route

through the undercling/lieback at the top of the corner. Instead of moving back left to the finishing headwall of

Brady's

, bust right along the prominent, arching seam. Utilize non-positive handholds and frustrating feet to get across the slightly overhanging wall. At the end of the traverse, squeeze the "Sand Dollar" crimp and deadpoint with all you've got into the vertical seam on your way to the anchors.

This is definitely a major line on Lemon's East Side, climbing most of the plum of

Brady's Route

then busting across the steeper, striped wall. It is certainly among the hardest pitches in the Durango area. It requires a lot of climbing and diverse techniques to get to a pretty hard set of moves with some creative rope management along the way. Get psyched and enjoy.
content.protection:
16 bolts and chain anchors. Bring long draws and slings to minimize drag on

Brady's

then some longer or double draws for the difficult clips on the crux traverse. Use a 70m rope to descend (or lower twice from the bolted belay on the ledge).
content.location:
The Sand Dollar climbs most of

Brady's Route

, which begins behind the tree and just left of a large, mungy, left-facing corner. The Sand Dollar climbs right from the top of the right-facing corner on

Brady's

across the prominent seam in the dark-colored headwall.

content.description: This is one of the best climbs in Durango that I have ever been on.  The climb starts up a slab.  At the top of the slab, the climb turns into a slightly overhanging wall.  The climber goes through a few steep, overhanging moves, to a confusing roof.  Climb past the roof and climb the bolts that are in the rightward direction to the top.
content.location: Walk past the warm up area to the next area of climbing.  There is a big tree at the very base of the slab that starts the climb.  The first bolt is in the middle of the slab, before the climber reaches the more vertical to steep rock climbing.

content.description:
Pyromania is a great climb just right of

Holy Grail

. It works through a spicy start, thought-provoking cruxes, and an incredible sustained finish.
content.protection: Bolts. As usual for Lemon, be confident at the grade. Dont blow the 2nd clip.
content.location:
This is between

Holy Grail

and

Symonizer

.

content.description: Pebbles is a fun, well-bolted climb for people working this grade.
content.protection: 6 bolts to fixed steel cable draws.
content.location: This is now the first route on the right side of the east side.

content.description: Start by climbing easy low-angle rock past one bolt, then up the vertical black face and arete.  There are fun and interesting moves on this short but quality route.
content.location: From the first routes, hike up the small hill and continue to a right-facing corner.  This route is on the left-hand side of the first tall, steep wall encountered.

content.description:
Lemon Drop is located on the right side of the big ledge.  Climb the short approach pitch, belay, and then walk over to the right and set up another belay on beefy anchor bolts.

Climb past five bolts and two deceptive cruxs to reach the anchor.
content.location:
Climb the short 5.9 approach pitch and go past

Flat Track

to the end of the ledge.

content.description:
This is a good splitter for Durango standards. It has a little bit of an odd ball location, but this is a fun, traditional challenge.

It starts on a ledge that is most easily accessible by rappelling into it. You start by climbing up a crack that's not the greatest rock, but the gear seems decent. At this point, the climbing starts to become difficult, and there is a funky place to protect that I couldn't find a good gear placement with besides a green Omega cam. While protected by a fairly good cam placement, but not the best rock, pull on some shallow but positive finger locks that lead to a good stance  A little higher in the splitter a #6 stopper and a #0.3 BD cam went in pretty well after digging out the placements. At this point, the crack turns into a seam, which is probably protectable, but hard to place gear on. I found some really fun, positive-feeling face holds to the left of the seam, which were really committing and far apart. Those couple of moves lead to a flared hand jam and some possible air time over marginal gear. Pull the flared hand jam to a jug! You can relax a little and finally place a textbook HB placement, which I believe was a #4 HB. You climb a little higher, and the granite crack eases off and becomes a fantastic splitter from fingers to fist jams.

This is the only granite splitter I have climbed in the Durango area. It is unique to the area.

I headpointed this climb, with some traffic it would probably clean up well. I thought rope soloing the route was really fun, quick, and easy to set up. It helped me to plan the gear out before leading it.
content.protection: Offset and standard stoppers and a set of BD cams from #0.3 to #4. Bring doubles of fingers to thin hands. There are two anchor bolts at the top of the cliff.
content.location: Park at the East parking area, and head straight to the river from there. You will run into a cliff line in 5 minutes, follow the cliff line until you find bolts and chain anchors.

content.description:
Many of the harder lines in the Durango area seem to be somewhat enigmatic, and Jack Frost is no exception. Most folks know it as "the hard thing next to

Rasta Man!!

" and give it a glance as they walk on to better known routes. As it turns out, this one is really good.

Start up an easy slab past two bolts and stand up on the slightly gravelly ledge. The climbing changes dramatically here. Stretch up high to clip the third bolt (a stick clip from the ledge would be a legit tactic as this bolt is especially hard to get a draw onto), and surf into immediate difficulties. The angle eases, and good holds emerge to lead one to the elegant black and gray headwall, where one's ability to use very small, sloping holds will dictate success.
content.location:
Jack Frost begins directly behind the large tree in the middle of the wall. Tie in about 20 feet right of

Rasta Man!!

.

content.description:
This is a great route to the left of "

Holy Grail

". Starts of runout but easy slab  in to a right facing corner. At the top of the corner climb steep face to large ledge. Follow small dihedral up to bolt and then climb bolted face to 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.protection: 11 bolts, 2 bolt anchor, 70 meter rope, Optional: #0.4 or 0.5 Camalot.
content.location:
This is to the left of "

Holy Grail

."

content.description:
Start on

Pyromania

, and climb up past 5 bolts. Cut right at the top of the dihedral, and clip a bolt. Hand traverse up and right on some pretty good holds until you reach

Simonizer

. A long draw on either end of the traverse helps minimize rope drag. Climb the last 5 bolts of

Simonizer

. Hot Jimmy felt slightly more sustained to me, when compared to

Simonizer

.
content.protection:
12 bolts total (9Â draws if the last 3 on

Simonizer

are still fixed).
content.location:
Start on

Pyromania

, and finish on

Simonizer

.

content.description: This is a great route that ascends the tallest section of the cliff.  A 70m rope is nice to lower off from the anchor.  There are two crux sections with a ledge between them to shake out. One of the best sport climbs in the Durango area.
content.location: Walk upstream from the first routes, up a small hill and continue to the tallest section of the cliff.  The route starts a little past a large tree near the base.

content.description: Climb the arete & the face to the right of the arete. At the top of the arete are funky looking stacked blocks - avoid them. They appear to be stable at the moment, but who knows how long that will last? The route moves right just below the blocks (crux) and continues up a featured face.
content.location:
About 25 feet right of

Pebbles

is a sharp arete, the right side of the arete is The Happy Hooker.

content.description: Start on low angle slab for about two bolts. At the top of the slab, the wall becomes vertical to overhanging for three bolts. Can you figure out the boulder problem?
content.location:
This is the first route on the hard wall. It's directly right of

Beowulf

.

content.description: The Great Gazoo ascends a fun, steep arete with a hard finish.
content.location: It is on the far left side of the Warm-up Wall, just around the corner on the arete.

content.description:
P1 - Climb the first few bolts of

Interfearon

then move left at a ledge to a bolted anchor.

P2 - Climb the face above past four more bolts (11c).
content.location:
Use the same start as

Interfearon

, then step left.

content.description:
P1 - Climb a slabby start and step right onto the black face and finish at a large ledge (5.9).

Eds. named Dirt Track

.

P2 - Do a mantle move off the belay and then follow the right-facing, right-angling dihedral to the top (5.11c).
content.location:
Look for the dihedral on P2 that is a little downstream of

Brady's Route

.

content.description:
Do the same start as

Interfearon

, but break left after

Interfearon's

1st bolt to 3 bolts left in the dark rock. Head to the same lower ledge as

Interfearon

, climb the techy face 3 bolt section, then break left to the arete at

Interfearon's

6th bolt to a 6 bolt independent finish left of

Interfearon

. The crux is at the last two bolts of the route. Mantel on to the ledge, and clip the anchors.

The route;s name is very much in relation to

Interfearon

.
content.protection: 13 quickdraws with steel biners at the anchors. Bring a couple 2' draws if you want to.

content.description:
Climb a short 5.11 beginning section to a 20 foot runout on 5.5 terrain, gain the headwall, and climb another 30 feet to get to the first crux, a heinous series of undercling crimps leading to where

The Sand Dollar

branches off of

Brady's Route

. Recover as much as you can on the undercling jug before charging across the notoriously pumpy

Sand Dollar

traverse.

There is a possible direct finish to this line that would significantly up the difficulty.
content.location:
Begin with the next start right of

Brady's Route

.

content.description: Climb the arete & the face to the left of the arete.
content.location:
About 25 feet right of

Pebbles

is a sharp arete, the left side of the arete is Chattanooga Choo Choo.

content.description: This is a quality route that is sustained in difficulty.  Start up the slab which quickly becomes steeper.  Trend right up towards a right-facing dihedral feature and then finish straight up with more steep face moves.
content.location: Walk upstream from the first routes, up a small hill and continue to the tallest section of the cliff. The route starts near a large tree at the base.

content.description: This is the rightmost route on the Rasta Wall BEFORE the small groove. There is one more short route right of the groove on its own pillar. Climb the right side of the slab, passing a bolt. At the base of the upper headwall, utilize a key undercling to clip the next bolt and begin upward. Some big moves between good holds lead to very big moves between very small holds. An odd, triangular block, which appears is not to be attached, provides some help out right. Crimp hard and God speed!
content.location: This is on the right side of Rasta Wall. There appear to be two starts which come back together. I described the left version.

content.description:
This route climbs through the fun crux of

Rasta Man!!

then cuts left instead of right. Climb up through an easy roof to a second thin crimpy crux.

This variation was super fun but didn't seem much harder than

Rasta Man!!

, since you get a great no hands rest under the upper roof below the second crux.
content.location: Walk past the warm-up area to the next area of climbing. There is a big tree at the very base of the slab that starts the climb. The first bolt is in the middle of the slab, before the climber reaches the more vertical to steep rock climbing.
